Back (EN): Watch out for the boss! / Be alert around the boss!
Notes: Colombian workplace warning. 'Pilas' = batteries, but means 'be alert/careful'. Used when boss is nearby or when you need to focus. Example: ¡Pilas con el jefe que viene para acá! = Watch out for the boss, he's coming this way!

Back (EN): I have a lot of work
Notes: Colombian slang for work. 'Camello' literally = camel, but in Colombia = work/job. Very common. More intense than 'trabajo'. Example: Tengo mucho camello esta semana, no puedo salir = I have a lot of work this week, I can't go out

Back (EN): I'm working hard / I'm grinding
Notes: 'Camellar' = to work (verb from 'camello'). 'Duro' = hard. Colombian way to say you're working intensely. Example: Estoy camelléndole duro para terminar el proyecto = I'm working hard to finish the project

Back (EN): What time do you get off work?
Notes: Standard Colombian question. 'Salir del trabajo' = leave work. Used for planning after-work activities. Example: ¿A qué horas sales del trabajo hoy? Nos tomamos algo = What time do you get off work today? Let's grab drinks

Back (EN): I have meetings all day
Notes: Common office complaint. 'Reunión' = meeting. Colombian office culture has many meetings. Example: Uy parce, tengo reunión todo el día, qué pereza = Ugh dude, I have meetings all day, what a drag
Reply: Estoy en reuniones todo el día

Back (EN): I had to stay late / I had to work late
Notes: 'Me tocó' = I had to (Colombian expression). Common workplace complaint. Example: Me tocó quedarme hasta tarde porque el jefe pidió el informe para mañana = I had to stay late because the boss asked for the report tomorrow

Back (EN): Can you do me a favor? / Help me out?
Notes: Colombian slang for favor. 'Catorce' = fourteen, but means favor. Unique to Colombia. Example: Parce, ¿me haces un catorce? Necesito que cubras mi turno = Dude, can you do me a favor? I need you to cover my shift

Back (EN): I'm swamped with work / I'm tied up with work
Notes: 'Embolatado' = busy/overwhelmed (Colombian). 'Embolatar' = to get tangled up. Example: Estoy embolatado con trabajo, no puedo ir al almuerzo = I'm swamped with work, I can't go to lunch

Back (EN): I failed the exam
Notes: 'Rajarse' = to fail (Colombian student slang). Very common among students. Example: Me rajé en el examen de matemáticas, toca repetir = I failed the math exam, I have to retake it

Back (EN): Did you study for the exam?
Notes: 'Parcial' = midterm/exam (Colombian university term). Common student question. Example: ¿Estudiaste para el parcial de mañana o vamos a hacer vaca? = Did you study for tomorrow's exam or should we pool money (for something)?

Front (ES): Tengo que entregar la tarea mañana
Back (EN): I have to turn in the homework tomorrow
Notes: 'Entregar' = to turn in/submit. Standard expression. Example: Tengo que entregar la tarea mañana y todavía no he empezado = I have to turn in the homework tomorrow and I haven't even started

Back (EN): Pay attention to me! / Listen to me!
Notes: Colombian command. 'Parar bolas' = to pay attention (literally: stop balls). Used by teachers, parents, bosses. Example: ¡Páreme bolas que esto es importante! = Pay attention to me, this is important!

Back (EN): I didn't do the homework
Notes: Simple student confession. Very common excuse. Example: Profe, no hice la tarea porque se me fue el internet = Teacher, I didn't do the homework because my internet went out

Back (EN): I'm studying for the quiz
Notes: 'Quiz' used in Colombia (English loan word). Common in universities. Example: Estoy estudiando para el quiz de historia, ¿me ayudas? = I'm studying for the history quiz, can you help me?

Front (ES): Voy a parchar con los manes
Back (EN): I'm going to hang out with the guys
Notes: 'Parchar' = to hang out (Colombian slang). 'Manes' = guys/dudes. Very common youth expression. Example: Voy a parchar con los manes en el parque = I'm going to hang out with the guys at the park
Reply: Voy a salir con los amigos

Back (EN): Should we party this weekend? / Want to go out this weekend?
Notes: 'Rumbear' = to party (Colombian). 'Finde' = weekend (short for fin de semana). Very common. Example: ¿Vamos a rumbear este finde o qué más? = Should we party this weekend or what?

Back (EN): I love going out for drinks
Notes: 'Salir a tomar' = to go out drinking. Common Colombian activity. Example: Me encanta salir a tomar con mis parceros los viernes = I love going out for drinks with my friends on Fridays

Back (EN): Should we play soccer on Saturday?
Notes: Standard invitation. Football/soccer is huge in Colombia. Example: ¿Jugamos fútbol el sábado en la cancha del barrio? = Should we play soccer Saturday at the neighborhood field?

Front (ES): Voy al gym todos los días
Back (EN): I go to the gym every day
Notes: 'Gym' used in Colombia (English loan). Fitness culture growing in cities. Example: Voy al gym todos los días después del trabajo = I go to the gym every day after work

Back (EN): I like cooking at home
Notes: Standard expression. Colombian home cooking culture. Example: Me gusta cocinar en casa los domingos para la familia = I like cooking at home on Sundays for the family

Back (EN): We're going out to eat on Sunday
Notes: 'Salir a comer' = to go out to eat. Common family/social activity. Example: Salimos a comer el domingo al restaurante de comida típica = We're going out to eat Sunday at the traditional food restaurant

Back (EN): Should we go to the movies tonight?
Notes: Standard invitation. 'Cine' = cinema/movies. Common date/friend activity. Example: ¿Vamos al cine esta noche a ver la nueva película? = Should we go to the movies tonight to see the new film?

Back (EN): I'm reading a cool book
Notes: 'Bacano' = cool (Colombian slang from Bogotá/Cachaco region). Common for describing enjoyable things. Example: Estoy leyendo un libro bacano sobre historia colombiana = I'm reading a cool book about Colombian history

Front (ES): Me gusta montar en bici los domingos
Back (EN): I like riding my bike on Sundays
Notes: Cycling is huge in Colombia (national sport for many). 'Montar en bici' = ride bike. Example: Me gusta montar en bici los domingos por la Ciclovía = I like riding my bike on Sundays on the Ciclovía (car-free streets)

Back (EN): I'm going to yoga class
Notes: Wellness trend in Colombian cities. Standard expression. Example: Voy a clase de yoga todas las mañanas antes del trabajo = I'm going to yoga class every morning before work

Back (EN): Should we grab a coffee? / Want to get a coffee?
Notes: 'Tinto' = black coffee (Colombian). 'Echarse un tinto' = grab coffee. Very Colombian. Example: ¿Nos echamos un tinto en la tarde para charlar? = Should we grab a coffee in the afternoon to chat?

Front (ES): Vamos a hacer vaca para la salida
Back (EN): Let's pool money for the trip
Notes: 'Hacer vaca' = to pool money together (Colombian slang). Common for group activities. Example: Vamos a hacer vaca para la salida a Santa Marta = Let's pool money for the trip to Santa Marta

Back (EN): What an awesome concert!
Notes: 'Chimba' = awesome/cool (Colombian, slightly vulgar but common). Used among friends. Example: ¡Qué chimba de concierto estuvo anoche! = What an awesome concert last night was!

Front (ES): Me quedo en casa a descansar
Back (EN): I'm staying home to rest
Notes: Self-care expression. Common after busy week. Example: Este fin de semana me quedo en casa a descansar, estoy muy cansado = This weekend I'm staying home to rest, I'm very tired

Back (EN): Should we go for a walk?
Notes: Simple invitation. Walking culture in Colombian parks. Example: ¿Salimos a caminar por el parque después de comer? = Should we go for a walk through the park after eating?

Back (EN): We have to study all night / I need to pull an all-nighter
Notes: 'Toca' = it's necessary/we have to (Colombian). Common student struggle. Example: Toca estudiar toda la noche para el final de mañana = We have to study all night for tomorrow's final
Reply: Hay que estudiar toda la noche

Back (EN): Can you pass me the notes? / Can you share your notes?
Notes: Common student request. 'Apuntes' = class notes. Example: ¿Me pasas los apuntes de la clase de ayer? No pude ir = Can you pass me yesterday's class notes? I couldn't go

Back (EN): I have class until five
Notes: Standard schedule information. Example: Tengo clase hasta las cinco, después nos vemos = I have class until five, we'll meet after
Reply: Las clases terminan a las cinco

Back (EN): The teacher is very demanding / strict
Notes: 'Profe' = teacher/professor (informal). 'Exigente' = demanding. Common student complaint. Example: El profe de química es muy exigente, siempre pide mucha tarea = The chemistry teacher is very demanding, he always asks for lots of homework

Back (EN): qué pereza trabajar!
Notes: I don't feel like working! / What a drag to work!
Reply: 'Qué pereza' = what laziness/drag (Colombian expression). Very common complaint. Example: ¡Uy, qué pereza trabajar los lunes! = Ugh, I don't feel like working on Mondays!

Back (EN): We're screwed with work / Too bad about work
Notes: 'Paila' = screwed/too bad (Colombian slang). Expresses resignation. Example: Paila con el trabajo, nos toca quedarnos hasta tarde = We're screwed with work, we have to stay late
Reply: Nos fue mal con el trabajo

Back (EN): Should we meet up with the group? / See you with the crew?
Notes: 'Parche' = group of friends/crew (Colombian). Different from 'parchar'. Example: ¿Nos vemos en el parche del sábado? = Should we meet up with the group on Saturday?

Back (EN): I love going to the stadium
Notes: Football culture. 'Estadio' = stadium. Passionate Colombian fans. Example: Me encanta ir al estadio a ver jugar al Nacional = I love going to the stadium to watch Nacional play

Back (EN): I'm going to learn English
Notes: Common goal in Colombia. Example: Voy a aprender inglés este año para mejorar en el trabajo = I'm going to learn English this year to improve at work

Front (ES): Estoy en un curso de cocina
Back (EN): I'm in a cooking class / I'm taking a cooking course
Notes: Growing hobby in Colombian cities. Example: Estoy en un curso de cocina italiana los miércoles = I'm in an Italian cooking class on Wednesdays

Back (EN): When is the deadline?
Notes: 'Deadline' used in Colombian offices (English loan). Example: ¿Cuándo es el deadline del proyecto? = When is the project deadline?

Back (EN): I have to work from home / do home office
Notes: 'Home office' used in Colombia (English loan). Post-pandemic common. Example: Mañana tengo que hacer home office porque viene el plomero = Tomorrow I have to work from home because the plumber is coming

Back (EN): I got promoted at work
Notes: 'Ascender' = to promote. Good news to share. Example: ¡Me ascendieron en el trabajo! Ahora soy gerente = I got promoted at work! Now I'm a manager

Back (EN): I'm going to quit / I'm going to resign
Notes: 'Renunciar' = to quit/resign. Big decision. Example: Voy a renunciar el próximo mes, ya conseguí otro trabajo = I'm going to quit next month, I already got another job

Back (EN): What do you do? / What do you do for work?
Notes: Standard question when meeting someone. 'Dedicarse a' = to work as/dedicate yourself to. Example: ¿A qué te dedicas? - Soy ingeniero de sistemas = What do you do? - I'm a systems engineer

Back (EN): I work in digital marketing
Notes: Professional introduction. Example: Trabajo en marketing digital para una empresa de tecnología = I work in digital marketing for a tech company

Back (EN): Do you have to wake up early tomorrow?
Notes: 'Madrugar' = to wake up early. Common question when planning evening activities. Example: ¿Tienes que madrugar mañana o podemos quedarnos hasta tarde? = Do you have to wake up early tomorrow or can we stay out late?

Back (EN): I wake up at six / I get up at six
Notes: Daily routine. Example: Me levanto a las seis para hacer ejercicio antes del trabajo = I wake up at six to exercise before work
